results.title: Time after time
results.creator_credit: Herb Jaffe, Warner Bros Pictures, Orion Pictures Corporation and Nicholas Meyer
results.brief_description: An extraordinary premise lies at the heart of this fantasy thriller: in nineteenth century London, H.G. Wells (Malcolm McDowell) invents a time machine and inadvertently transports himself as well as the notorious Jack The Ripper (David Warner) to modern day San Francisco. What follows is at turns comic and terrifying as fish-out-of-water Wells seeks out the blood thirsty killer whose brutal rampage continues across the city. Whilst on the surface this picture makes innovative use of the quirks of time travel; underneath, “Time after time” investigates the utopian visions of a nineteenth century idealist as compared to the reality of twentieth century America; a society where Jack The Ripper finds himself thoroughly at home. Cast also includes Mary Steenburgen.

results.title: Time's Up
results.creator_credit: Daniela Torsh, Film Australia Women's Film Unit and Cynthia Connop
results.brief_description: A history of the campaign for equal pay for women in Australia. The film focuses on the ACTU test case, using the nursing profession, for equal pay for work of “comparable value”. It features ACTU unionist, Jenny Acton, nurse, Alex Anderson, and feminist Zelda D’Aprano who created news in Melbourne in 1972 by chaining herself to the door of the Commonwealth Government offices as a protest against unequal pay rates. A combination of interviews and archival footage.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Daniela Torsh, Film Australia Women’s Film Unit and Cynthia Connop

results.title: Time
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Dance series”
For the dancer, time is the awareness of duration. The film moves from the traditional musical definition of time into other areas of the time sense.

results.title: Timboon Consolidated School
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and E.J. Perry
results.brief_description: Makes an argument for the consolidation of local small rural schools into large purpose built centralised establishments with a post-primary school element. Presents the organisational elements involved: bussing, staffing, design, curriculum etc.

results.title: Timber fences and gates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Do It Yourself Home Video Workshop. Series 1”.
Enables the beginner to construct fences and gates with professional results. It introduces various fencing and gate designs, advising the viewer on material and tool requirements. It suggests wood and general preparation techniques and finally advises on the construction and assembly of gates and fences.

results.title: Timber
results.creator_credit: Robert Landucci, Earle Noble, Crest Films and Gary Payne
results.brief_description:
A non-narrated look at the logging and milling of timber in Canada. Raises issues about the environment and use of technology and transport.
Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Tim Roth: made in Britain
results.creator_credit: BBC, Damon Thomas and Emily Fielden
results.brief_description: Profiling British actor Tim Roth who has worked extensively in Hollywood (Reservoir dogs, Pulp fiction, Planet of the apes), this documentary was filmed in 1999, when Roth, tired of the actor’s lot, was directing and promoting his directorial debut “The War zone”. In interview Roth discusses his influences, experiences both as a fledgling actor and successful star, fame, his upbringing, hopes for the future, feelings about his craft and desire to retire from acting and pursue directing. As a young thespian Roth started off in theatre before landing a key role in “Made in Britain”, a controversial TV movie about juvenile delinquency, which enabled Roth to forge ahead with a successful film career. Roth was subsequently cast in “Jumpin’ at the Boneyard” (1992) which led to a key role in “Reservoir dogs” (1992), Quentin Tarantino’s ultra-violent heist film that made several unknown actors famous. Also interviewed are school friends, colleagues, fellow actors Ray Winstone, Gary Oldman, Chris Penn and John Hurt, Mike Leigh who directed Roth in “Meantime” (1981), and Tom Stoppard director and writer of “Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead” (1990). Features extensive footage of Tim Roth shooting “The War zone” using inexperienced actors and shows Roth dealing with the mixed critical reception that his film received in the UK.
